Award.AwardTitle: ADVANCE: Catalyzing Gender Equity at a Research Institution in the Deep South

Division.LongName: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

Award.AbstractNarration:
Louisiana State University (LSU) will implement an ADVANCE Catalyst project to conduct an institutional self-assessment to investigate gender inequities in academic leadership and research and to develop a meaningful equity strategic plan to address those inequities. The regional characteristics of LSU confound the experiences of women from diverse backgrounds and provide an important institutional context for understanding and advancing approaches to address systemic gender inequities within a research university, located in one of the most diverse regions of the country. The LSU ADVANCE Catalyst project will focus on understanding micro-climates within the university, communicating an inclusive and innovative plan for faculty success through institutional data analyses and strategic communication, and developing an inclusive five-year equity action plan. The LSU project will also investigate strategic communication as an institutional change lever for advancing change in diverse contexts.

The LSU ADVANCE Catalyst project will build on gendered organizations theories and use the human performance technology (HPT) model, which provides a systematic and comprehensive approach to improving the work performance of individuals in an organization by investigating the lived experiences of workers (i.e. faculty members), the work that they do, and the environment in which they conduct their work. Drawing on this model, LSU will examine the inequities in the faculty experience and organizational practices. Overall, the LSU ADVANCE Catalyst will lay the groundwork for engaging the campus at multiple levels in an equity strategic plan with a focus on advancing faculty productivity and innovation. This institutional context also provides a unique intersectional lens from which to study these problems and develop interventions that promote the success of all faculty regardless of their diverse identities.

The NSF ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of diverse faculty in academic institutions. Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in policies, processes, practices, and the organizational culture and climate. ADVANCE "Catalyst" awards provide support for institutional equity assessments and the development of five-year faculty equity strategic plans at an academic, non-profit institution of higher education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Louisiana State University (LSU) has implemented an ADVANCE Catalyst project to conduct an institutional self-assessment to investigate gender inequities in academic leadership and research and to develop a meaningful equity strategic plan to address those inequities. To understand the dynamics impacting the representation and progress of STEM women faculty at LSU, the LSU ADVANCE-IT leadership team conducted a landscape analysis, which included (1) a profile of faculty by rank and gender; (2) an in-depth analysis of the faculty's lived experiences through the Faculty Job Satisfaction Survey implemented by the Harvard University Collaborative on Academic Careers in Higher Education (COACHE) [1] and faculty focus groups; and (3) an institutional self-assessment of work-life balance policies [2]. Together, these provided a deeper understanding of the impact of gender on LSU faculty outcomes, in hiring, tenure and promotion, leadership, job satisfaction, work-life balance, and research productivity.  

  

Intellectual Merit 

The LSU ADVANCE Catalyst project used the human performance technology (HPT) model, which provides a systematic and comprehensive approach to improving the work performance of individuals in an organization by investigating the lived experiences of workers (i.e. faculty members), the work that they do, and the environment in which they conduct their work. Herein, we examined the faculty experience and relevant organizational practices.  

 

Our institutional self-study has shown that LSU women experience some of the same barriers as others across the U.S. system of higher education; however, these experiences are confounded by the subtle dynamics of Southern culture.  The reported instances of marginalization, when combined with gender-based, cultural taxation (e.g., illustrated by unbalanced service loads), result in a system of inequity marked by limited access to the extant power structures. Moreover, biases, marginalization, and exclusion, while common experiences reported by LSU STEM women faculty, are dynamics not necessarily well understood by their male colleagues. Our assessment captured data that suggest that male faculty members underestimate the barriers that their female colleagues experience.  

 

The findings from the institutional self-study have laid the groundwork for engaging our campus at multiple levels in an equity strategic plan with a focus on advancing faculty productivity and innovation. To this end, our project designed a five-year equity plan to address the paradigm of inequities in our institution. We seek to improve the campus climate for gender equity using the systems change model to promote a greater awareness of bias, marginalization, institutional racism, and institutional sexism and how these impact faculty progression, productivity, and integration into the campus STEM community. Our priority areas focus on (a) department microcultures, (b) academic leadership, (c) critical conversations, (d) policies for change, and (e) studies of systems change. Each of these areas center on the six levers for systems change [3, 4].   

 

Broader Impacts 

LSU is situated in the Deep South region of the country which has a cultural legacy of segregation, patriarchal leadership, and socioeconomic complexities. Despite this legacy, LSU has made remarkable progress in admitting and graduating students from historically underrepresented groups.  Using the HPT model, we have sought to better understand the current conditions and envision a future that supports a more productive, innovative, and demographically complex faculty. The dissemination of this approach will add to the knowledge base of best practices for advancing the success of all in the academy [5-9]. 

 

1. Benson, R.T. and J. Kim, Faculty Job Satisfaction Survey, Collaborative on Academic Careers in Higher Education (COACHE), Editor. 2021: Harvard University. 

2. Kelly Mack, N.C., Patrice McDermott, Abigail Stewart, Gender Values Institutional Self-Assessment, P.K. (PKal), Editor. 2017, Association of American Colleges & Universities (AAC&U),. 

3. Kania, J., M. Kramer, and P. Senge, The water of systems change. 2018. 

4. Shi, L. and S. Moser, Transformative climate adaptation in the United States: Trends and prospects. Science, 2021. 372(6549): p. eabc8054. 

5. Jeong, S., Sim, E., Wilson-Kennedy, Z., & Peterson, C. (Under review). Institutional Paradox: Unraveling the Diverse Realities among Faculty Members in a Deep-South, Research-intensive University in the United States. 

6. Jeong. S., Sim, E., & Lee, Y. (Submitted) The interplay of multiple-layered social identities and job satisfaction: A latent class analysis. Proceeding of the 2024 Academy of Management Annual Virtual Meeting. 

7. Sim, E., & Jeong, S. (2024). A multi-level analysis of faculty satisfaction, University Forum for Human Resource Development, Lisbon, Portugal. 

8. Jeong, S., Sim, E., Wilson-Kennedy, Z., & Peterson, S. (2024). A Qualitative, systematic comparison of the faculty experience by gender and race in a research-intensive university: An inter-categorical intersectionality study. Proceedings of the 2024 Academy of Human Resource Development International Research Conference in Americas, Arlington, Virginia. 

9. Jeong, S., Wilson-Kennedy, Z., & Weng, J. (2022). The pipeline left behind: The experiences of STEM women faculty of color in comparison with other racial and gender groups. The ADVANCE Resource and Coordination Network’s 2022 Equity in STEM Community Convening, Washington, DC.
